paragraphs.text: Germany: a beacon and a force for good in Europe.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: We are lucky to have today's Germany
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When Chancellor Merkel arrived in London last week
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: she came as the accomplished leader of Europe's most successful liberal democracy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Germany's economic strength is taken for granted
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: more subtly
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we also take for granted that this is an essentially good country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is not going to assuage any demons by behaving aggressively to its neighbours or blaming foreigners for any of its problems
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is quietly and determinedly going to attempt to anchor Europe in the same successful combination of liberal democracy, social solidarity and productive capitalism that it enjoys
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it has the economic and moral wherewithal to do just that
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This very new country - after all German reunification was completed just 25 years ago- could be so different
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It could have a poisonous political movement aiming to restore Napoleonic glories riding high in the polls - see the Front National in France
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It could be captured by venal, vested-interest groups locking the economy in permanent stagnation like Italy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It could be in thrall to a know-nothing political right whose objective is to run the country in the interests of its top 1% like the US's Republicans
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It could be led by a self-regarding nationalist such as Russia's Mr Putin
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It could live in a cultural time-warp like today's Britain, hankering to restore the lost certainties of the 1950s
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Germany is none of those things
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it were
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Europe would be fundamentally and worryingly unstable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Rather
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: this is a firmly liberal democratic country looking forward in the 21st century
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because its relationship to history, as director of the British Museum Neil MacGregor argues in his revelatory and illuminating book Germany, compels it never to look back
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Germany can only face its otherwise unintelligible historical crimes, genocide and futile millions of war dead with a resolve to never again make the same mistakes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Its capital city, Berlin, forces its citizens every day to confront the fact that it exterminated six million Jews in its striking Holocaust memorial
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: no other world capital so uncompromisingly has built monuments at its heart to force it constantly to confront past disasters
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What does it mean to be us is a question every country asks, searching its history to reproduce whatever success it might have once enjoyed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: MacGregor's argument is that because Germany cannot take comfort or define itself by imagined past glories, it is free of imprisoning and destructive myths
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It has become, of necessity, a force for good, too little recognised in Britain in part
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because we still define ourselves as a victor over Germany when it was evil
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Angela Merkel chose to spend some hours of her time in London visiting the Germany exhibition at the British Museum
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: an exhibition MacGregor has curated alongside his book
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: MacGregor believes Britain does not understand today's Germany, the complexities that delivered it or why it thinks as it does
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Merkel agrees
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The point of her British trip was not to devise ways of helping Cameron win his EU referendum in 2017
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: about which she was stubbornly reticent
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It was very publicly to endorse MacGregor's view of today's Germany before his exhibition closes later this month - and perhaps trigger a different debate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: MacGregor organises the exhibition so that the first big quote you see is Goethe and Schiller's 1796 declaration: "Germany? Where is it?/ I do not know where to find such a country."
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: There are eight different maps of ever-mutating German territory since 1500
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Thus the home of Immanuel Kant, its greatest philosopher, is Kalingrad (then Konigsberg)
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which is now in Russia
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: the city that most influenced its greatest poet (Goethe), Strasbourg, is now in France
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: From 1500 to 1806, "German-ness" expressed itself through the loose association of principalities, cities, dukedoms and minor states that was the shifting boundaries of the Holy Roman Empire until its defeat by Napoleon
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Then came the nation state that was first imperial
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: then Hitler's Germany
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Postwar division followed defeat, then reunification
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: For Germany, the nation state has been an aberrant, destructive interlude between the Holy Roman Empire and now the European Union - a 21st-century variant of the Holy Roman Empire, but with a single currency, market and trading rules
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For Germany, it is the only way to conceive of the future, and create a peaceful and productive Europe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Senior German officials talk privately in these terms, categories that bewilder the British still locked in fundamentally traditional political categories
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For its neighbours, one downside of Germany's recent past - 1920s hyperinflation - is its quasi- religious attachment to sound money and budgetary rectitude
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the greater German attachment, trumping everything, is to think and build forward recognising today's realities
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Thus the Greek political crisis - and the possible confrontation between Germany and the anti-austerity Greek left if it wins the elections- may have a happier outcome than the British consensus could ever imagine
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Syriza has the 30 super-rich Greek families that pay no tax and run Greece as a payola for their own interests in its sights as much as it is targeting Greece's suffocating external debt burden and excess of austerity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is also keenly aware that abandoning the euro for the drachma and detaching itself from the EU exposes Greece to both huge inflation and the tender mercies of Turkey
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The potential deal with Germany is clear
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The left will forge a proper liberal Greek democracy with the 30 families paying tax, secure the forgiveness of much of its external debt but stay in the euro
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the price will be that it continues with tough constraints on public spending
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: France is shaken to its core by recent events
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Germany will want to see the atrocities as the acts of a murderous cult fuelled by marginalisation rather than join in any putative clash of civilisations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It knows better than any other European country where that leads
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: why it will successfully handle its own backlash against Islam, Pegida
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Equally
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there is a British referendum on EU membership
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Germany will offer whatever British government the deal necessary to keep Britain in
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Its mission is to try to hold Europe together, keeping at bay the temptations of Islamophobia, nativism, political extremism and protectionism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It may not succeed
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: But imagine if it did not try or if Germany itself gave in to the same temptations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It would love Britain to recall that at different times it has fought alongside Germans, to drop its fixation with two world wars and now make common cause to build a great future
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Europe would be so much stronger
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we dared
paragraphs.label: assumption
